instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in quantifying land cover for the Ouagadougou metropolitan area between 2002 and 2013 using remote sensing techniques?
Output: Machine learning models, specifically a support vector regression approach, were utilized in quantifying land cover for the Ouagadougou metropolitan area between 2002 and 2013 using remote sensing techniques. The study used a Landsat-TM/ETM + /OLI time series and synthetically mixed training data. The researchers worked with biseasonal image stacks to account for spectral variability between the dry and rainy seasons. They also incorporated a new class called "seasonal vegetation" to describe surfaces that are soil and vegetation during parts of the year. By using these machine learning models, the researchers were able to produce fraction images of urban surfaces, soil, permanent vegetation, and seasonal vegetation for each time step. The statistical evaluation showed that a temporally generalized, hi-seasonal model over all time steps performed equally or better than yearly or mono-seasonal models and provided reliable cover fractions. These urban fractions were then used to visualize pixel-based spatial-temporal patterns of urban densification and expansion. Additionally, a simple rule set based on a seasonal vegetation to soil ratio was used to delineate areas of unplanned and planned settlements, contributing to monitoring urban development on a neighborhood scale.
